p: Okuda et al. [ 101] was one of the first authors to report the antitumor activity of Camellia spp. namely, C. oleifera and C. sinensis. Epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), the main polyphenol of green tea, was referenced as a “cancer preventing agent”. Later, many other studies proved the antitumor activity of Camellia spp being most of them associated with C. sinensis. The antitumor potential of this species was highly explored whether using raw C. sinensis leaves extracts, their purified compounds or their commercially available polyphenols alone or synergistically with the most used antitumor drugs.
